p.s: ShakespearesShakespeare's way of conveying the emotion of love to his audience is definetlydefinitely one of his most loved aspects as a poet.
In the following there is going to be discussed how he deals with this topic.
Shakespeare's way of writing is not really loyal to the Patriarchan ideal or even the original form of a sonnet which came from Italy.
Being somewhat of a rebel,Shakespeare created his own form of a sonnet and more importantly: the unusual way of describing love.
especially when writing to the Dark Lady,Shakespeare portrayed love different from the ideal.
He believed it could be mutual and concrete, and he described it way more human than it was ever described by anyone living in Elizabethan times.

He did not reduce love to it's perfect form; he described it in all of its facettesfacets with all its flaws and imperfections, while also describing the woman adressedaddressed in his sonnets as ugly, and loyal, even reeking of smell nothing like the ideal.
a good example for his way of writing is Sonnet 130, which we've discussed in class.
by doing so,Shakespeare creates his own, very special way of describing the emotion of love and thereby winning the audiencesaudience's interests or hearts over.

Although it doesn't always have to be filled with flaws, the poet manages to accurately illustrate the emotion; accurately enough to still be relevant in modern times, while being dead since the beginning of the 17th century.
The same can be said about Sonnet 18 as an example.
EventhoughEven though it is far more positively written then some other sonnets of his, it still has a quatrain solely describing the things that aren't perfect, making it complete.
In conclusion,Shakespeare has his special way when working with the emotion of love.
In my opinion, this is his secret of being one of the best poets to ever exist, along with his way of describing feelings extraordinary accurately with only words.
